title: letter-week-climate-forest-must-done-right
story: While doing this, Irsquod like to encourage the council to apply the mantra lsquoRight trees, right place, right reasonrsquo, or these trees and their future growth are doomed.We have all seen the damage that mono-culture planting can do to landscapes and wildle. Trees for this Climate Forest need to be native species that enhance bioersity, planted where they can thrive, connect isolated pockets of wildle and benefit our local communities.They should also be planted in a way that improves peoplersquos enjoyment of their neighbourhood, while capturing carbon, reducing pollution and mitigating flooding.The council should lead by example and take full advantage of its own parks, playing fields, school grounds, open spaces and verges to create wildle corridors of trees and hedgerows, while building a network of green spaces for the people of East Lothian to enjoy.The golfing community could also play a major role in this project.East Lothian will also need to sign up new development to a  per cent tree cover and make developers plant at least one tree per garden space created.This, along with boundary hedges and native flowering areas, should help achieve the councilrsquos ambitious carbon targets.The proposed Climate Forest must also take into account local communities and their much-loved large mature trees currently in situ.The landscape of our county is changing, letrsquos make it for the better with the right trees, in the right space for the right reason.T ProudfootVictoria RoadNorth Berwick

title: special-hand-crafted-bench-finds-home-longniddry-dean-woods
story: The oak dowel and beech bench was designed and hand carved by path warden Graham Pettigrew.The bench was installed in the woodland area with the help of East Lothian Council Countryside Rangers.The intricate design of the bench represents the countryside from the Lammermuirs to the coast, and the spalted insets resemble the pattern of East Lothianrsquos shorelines.Wood carver Graham said: ldquoWhen visiting Loch Garten Nature Reserve, we were inspired by the design of a seat there which showed the landscape of Scottish pines on mountain slopes.ldquoI wanted to design and make a seat which was similarly fitting for our own local environment and seemed to grow out of it and feel part of it.Since retirement, Graham has carved items for enjoyment.He added: ldquoI designed the seat at the end of last year to be made from Scottish larch, sourced from Drem sawmills, and spalted beech which was found with permission after tree-felling in Gosford Estate.ldquoThe seat is held together by oak dowels and construction took around two months.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe council is very proud of the work carried out by Graham Pettigrew in designing, making and installing the new bench, which was done in consultation with the Countryside Ranger Service.ldquoThe seat provides visitors to the Dean a place to rest for contemplation or just to enjoy the surrounding woodland and nature.Graham and his we Maxine are both path wardens for Longniddry Dean woods.Their hope is that the new seat will provide a place for reflection in a location that is often bathed in sunlight.One Facebook user said: ldquoThis is an absolutely stunning bench. I love walking through the Dean Woods, it is so relaxing ndash I will be heading there for a peek today.Another added: ldquoWhat a wonderful idea to have a bench there.

title: bridge-centre-haddington-preparing-reopen-groups-use
story: The Bridge Centre, which is used by organisations ranging from mother and toddler groups to the University of the Third Age, has been closed due to the coronavirus pandemic.Now, furloughed staff are ing with immediate effect to prepare the premises in line with Covid- secure measures.The first groups toto the centre, on Haddingtonrsquos Poldrate, will be priority groups that provide key or essential support to the community.More groups willthroughout May, with the aim, subject to any change in coronavirus restrictions, of being fully open for groups of all ages toto their activities by the start of the autumn term.Jenny Harper, chairwoman of the Lamp of Lothian, which owns the Bridge Centre ndash which was being used by up to , people a week before the pandemic ndash said that the buildings had been ldquoeerily quiet.She said: ldquoThe Lamp of Lothian Trust are delighted that the Bridge Centre and their activities will be reopening slowly but surely in the next few weeks and months, and I am fully aware of the caution and care the staff have been taking.ldquoThe buildings have been, like so many, eerily quiet, but that is not to say much has not been happening behind the scenes.ldquoThe Lammermuir Larder volunteers are offering a wonderful service to the community, as well as the Bridge Centre outreach team.ldquoWe have welcomed the Tyneside Tavern into the courtyard, opening when permitted and dovetailing with the Bridge Centre.ldquoHaddington House is fully let to local businesses and nearly all are ing to their inidual offices.ldquoThe Lamp continues to shine its light in the local community and we fully intend to extend our charitable operations as le s to normal this year.ldquoI would like to thank all our Friends of the Lamp and Trusts who have continued to support us, and to our tenants in Haddington House.ldquoThese incomes enable us to offer all the buildings at the Poldrate free, to the community and for the community.Although the Bridge Centre has been closed, the staff have not been idle.Online youth classes and music lessons have been taking place, while the community outreach team, along with the community wardens and police, have been out every weekend since June last year.Christmas and Easter appeals have been organised, while the Lammermuir Larder, which provides a local community food initiative set up to support people struggling financially, was established in February.The closure has also given the opportunity to see ldquomuch-needed maintenance carried out in the building.

title: iceland-costa-apply-signs-haddington-retail-park-moves-closer-opening
story: Two planning applications for signage relating to stores at Haddington Retail Park are with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Iceland Foods Ltd is looking to put signs on the front of its building, which will contain The Food Warehouse, which is the furthest west unit of the main building at Gateside.Meanwhile, Costa Limited is seeking permission for ious signage at its drive-thru coffee shop off the B.Aldi and Home Bargains will also be part of the retail park.

title: plans-bring-relay-life-event-dunbar-first-time
story: The Relay for Le event, which collects money for lesaving research, is set to be staged outside the townrsquos Hallhill Sports Centre next summer.A final date for the fundraiser, which would be coming to Dunbar for the first time, has not yet been confirmed but organisers are in early discussions with the representatives of the sports centre on Kellie Road.Carrie Lennon, Cancer Research UK relationship manager, is among those hoping to take part in the fundraiser, with the town close to her heart.Her uncle Greig Hannan , who was a talented musician and postman in Dunbar, was just  when he died in September  from kidney cancer.The dad-of-three, who played lead guitar in Setting Sons, a classic punk covers band, lived on the townrsquos Ash Grove and had also played football for Dunbar United and Cockburnspath FC.Carrie said: ldquoIrsquoll be lighting my own candle at Relay for Le Dunbar in memory of Greig and for other loved ones in my family who have been through cancer.ldquoWe are looking ahead to summer  with great hope and excitement.ldquoRelay for Le is an inspirational event.One of the most poignant parts of the Relay for Le event is the Candle of Hope ceremony, which take place as darkness falls and lights up the venue with dedicated candles, honouring every le touched by cancer.Candle bags are decorated and dedicated to loved ones lost to cancer, a friend or family member living with the disease, those who have survived, or hope for the future ndash a world where all cancers are cured.The ceremony is a chance for quiet remembrance, reflection and celebration.Carrie added: ldquoThe Candle of Hope ceremony is the only time that the relay stops as we come together as a community to honour everyone who has been affected by cancer, united in the belief that our fundraising is making a dference and that we will beat cancer.ldquoWersquod love for some more people to come forward to help shape and create this amazing event.ldquoDunbar, are you ready to relay During the relay event, team members take it in turns to walk around a track to show their solidarity in the fight to beat cancer, while a iety of stalls, games and music from performers provide entertainment.Members of the public interested in taking part in the event and raising funds for the charity are being invited to come forward.A new fundraising committee will be formed to make the East Lothian event a success.Every year, about#,#people are diagnosed with cancer in Scotland and one in two people#in the UK born after #will get cancer in their#letime.Cancer survival in the UK has doubled since the s and Cancer Research UKrsquos work has been at the heart of that progress.But more funds and supporters are needed.To find out more about how you can get involved in Relay for Le Dunbar, email Carrie.Lennon@cancer.org.uk

title: dunbar-schoolboy-parts-foot-hair-good-cause
story: Ansel Parkin has already unicycled and run his way to raising hundreds of pounds for East Lothian Foodbank and Comic Relief.Now, the Dunbar Primary School pupil has said goodbye to his long locks to boost the Little Princess Trust.Proud mum Kirsty told the Courier: ldquoHe is loving his new hair.ldquoSometimes he says that he misses his long hair but he really enjoys his new hair.ldquoHe has noticed his hair is growing exceptionally fast!The -year-old had been growing his hair for about two years ldquomostly because he could not decide on a haircut.His mum said that the youngster wanted to have it cut while in primary seven and also to mark the end of lockdown.On April , he made the trip to Jack and Ivy on Dunbar High Street for the change of style.Neighbour Aimee Muirhead was given the honour of chopping the Dunbar youngsterrsquos locks, which have been sent off to the Little Princess Trust.The charity provides real-hair wigs for youngsters who have lost their hair through cancer or due to other illnesses.A minimum of seven inches of hair is needed to make a wig, with donors urged to raise money and send their hair to the good cause.Kirsty, who lives in Dunbar with husband Dan and Anselrsquos brother Ebon, , said: ldquoAnselrsquos hair had become so long that it was actually at the end of lockdown that it seemed as good a time as any to mark it and do some fundraising.ldquoYou have to donate over six inches and his hair was probably I think about  centimetreslong and he had about  centimetrescut off.Ansel, who last spring unicycled  miles for East Lothian Foodbank alongside his brother, also raised more than pound through an online fundraising page.Then, earlier this year, he swapped one wheel for lacing up his running shoes in aid of Comic Relief.He was joined by classmate Jake Page in running a mile every hour for  hours.Jake was dressed as superhero lsquoThe Flashrsquo, while Ansel donned a pair of butterfly wings for the occasion.To support Ansel, go to uk.virginmoneygiving KirstyParkin

title: ross-high-rugby-club-delighted-newly-refurbished-gym
story: Found in the club on Blawearie Road, the new facility is currently open to adult players, who can take part in activities in line with the current coronavirus regulations and those set out by the Scottish Rugby Union.It is also hoped that, in future, youngsters from the townrsquos Recharge facility could have access to the gym.Ross Highrsquos players have not been able to fully train for seven months due to Covid rules, with restricted training taking place since April.Players have only now been able to resume regular training, the first time since November.Called the Chris Miller Fitness Suite after the clubrsquos long-time player and the projectrsquos major sponsor, the gym contains several weight benches, racks, weights, a bike machine, and two other weight machines.There is also a personal best board for players to mark and record their performance.A dumbbell rack will be the last piece of equipment installed, still to be purchased by the club.Almost all of the equipment was brand new, with the old second-hand pieces that used to be in place now no longer fit for purpose and not suitable for rugby.The gym, found near the changing facilities, is decorated in the clubrsquos colours.Work took place over seven months. The old gym was stripped bare, the walls painted, a new ventilation and sound system installed and new flooring put in.The club raised more than pound, in sponsorship from members, players, coaches and sponsors to help make the project a reality, while the Walk With Scott Foundation ndash whose founder, the late Scott Glynn, was the clubrsquos former president ndash and East Lothian Council also helped bring the gym to le.Due to Covid restrictions, players have to book a slot beforehand.Ryan Strachan, Ross Highrsquos rugby and business officer, said that with the season the club had had, the new gym was some good news.He added: ldquoA huge amount of work has gone into this project from initial fundraising, socially distanced work from a small group of volunteers and now organising safe re-opening for players using an online booking system.ldquoOn behalf of the club, a big thanks to our sponsors, contributors, the small group of highly committed volunteers and our suppliers.ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for membership and people wanting to help, we wouldnrsquot be able to do a lot of things.Younger players will be able to access the gym in due course in cooperation with Active Schools, while those who attend the townrsquos Recharge could also soon be able to use it.

title: new-colouring-book-east-lothian-reveals-rich-history
story: A History of East Lothian Colouring Book is a heartfelt tribute to the unique heritage of the county.The illustrations ndash based on the history of East Lothian ndash include the Roman Temple of Mithras at Musselburgh, the Siege of Haddington and detailed images of Scottish coastal industries.The book is being sold to raise funds for the Waggonway Project, which runs a heritage centre in Cockenzie celebrating the history of Scotlandrsquos first railway.Cockenziersquos Alan Braby, a founding member of the group and illustrator of the book, spoke about his new publication.He told the Courier: ldquoAs an archaeological illustrator living in East Lothian, the history, archaeology and local scenery is outstanding.ldquoIn my reconstruction drawings, I have always tried to include it all, from early prehistory to the unknown, but I have recently rediscovered events and incidents of the th and th centuries.ldquoFrom a large portfolio of images, we were able to select a few that gave a potted history of East Lothian that proved most suitable to this publication.The Waggonway Project was set up to protect and publicise the route of Scotlandrsquos first railway, the  Tranent-Cockenzie Waggonway.Ed Bethune, Waggonway Project chairman, was delight with the bookrsquos launch.He said: ldquoAlanrsquos work has been a big part of the success of the Waggonway Project since  and we are delighted to celebrate this by bringing his fantastic artwork to a wider audience of all ages.ldquoThe book is greatyou want to add colour, or evenyou just want a collection of superb archaeological reconstruction to admire, and we are very grateful to Alan for his generosity in donating the proceeds to our community heritage projects.Alanrsquos book is available for purchase on the Waggonway website: waggonway product-page alan-braby-s-east-lothian-colouring-book

title: refurbishment-alterations-planned-cockenzie-primary-school
story: East Lothian Council is seeking permission to make alterations, including the demolition of a redundant chimney, at Cockenzie Primary School.The planning application, which is being considered by the local authorityrsquos planning department, outlines the work proposed.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council anticipated that the work could be carried out during the school holidays.She said: ldquoSubject to planning approval, work will be carried out at Cockenzie Primary School over the summer holidays involving major external refurbishment.ldquoThis includes flat roofing works, rooflight and window replacement, installation of an external insulated render system and the demolition of a redundant chimney.ldquoIn addition, internal works include an electrical rewire, new lighting and suspended ceilings to be undertaken to five classrooms.ldquoThis is part of a rolling programme of primary school project works and maintenance.

title: new-owners-taking-drummohr-caravan-park
story: International real estate advisor Savills, on behalf of private clients, has completed the sale of Drummohr at Levenhall, Musselburgh, to employee-owned leisure, retail and distribution specialist WCF Ltd for an undisclosed amount.Jo Ritzema, managing director of WCF Ltd, said this was the companyrsquos first caravan, camping and glamping site in Scotland, with the nearest being a five-star facility at Herding Hill Farm near Hadrianrsquos Wall in Northumberland.She stressed that the company hoped to go on to increase its portfolio of camping and glamping sites in southern Scotland and the north of England.The site is developed to accommodate  luxury holiday letting lodges, seven of which have hot tubs,  touring caravans, tents and motorhomes, together with  glamping units.The site also includes a storage area for up to  touring caravans, a three-bedroom bungalow with hot tub, two amenity blocks and a shop.The .-acresite is situated in the formerly walled gardens of a monastery and was converted to a holiday park in . It has been owned and run by the same family since .Mrs Ritzema first visited Drummohr as a camper herself, saying it benefited from the draw of Edinburgh and the ldquobeautul coastline and countryside of East Lothian.She said that the company, which has its registered office at Brampton, near Carlisle, had started an external refurbishment programme at Drummohr involving painting and decorating, with further plans to ldquoupdate and upgrade the facilities such as lodges and glamping units.She said that the site had a large touring area for tents and caravans which would also be improved, with the amenity blocks, accommodating showers, toilets and laundry, refurbished. It was also planned to add an indoor area including a kitchen for campers.Mrs Ritzema added that, given the ldquosignicant growth in glamping, additional units would be provided subject to consultation and the necessary planning consents.She added that the seven staff members, one of them part-time, who worked at the site had been retained, with a recruitment process under way for a further three or four new employees.They either live on-site or in the local area, including Angie Purves, an East Lothian resident who has been promoted from office manager to take over the running of Drummohr.Mrs Ritzema said that everyone involved in the venture was ldquomadly excited by it all and added that a new website for the site would highlight local visitor attractions.Richard Prestwich, director in the leisure and trade team at Savills, said: ldquoHoliday parks have become exceptionally sought-after due to the growing trend for staycations. It is encouraging to witness new entrants, such as WCF, targeting the holiday parks market and competing with the existing multi-park owners that have traditionally dominated the marketplace.

title: josh-taylors-fiancee-danielle-murphy-ecstatic-win---hoping-start-wedding-planning
story: Danielle Murphy watched the fight from home in Haddington after Covid- restrictions prevented her from flying to Las Vegas.Josh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed world championDanielle told the Courier: ldquoI am absolutely ecstatic about his win, he has made history."All the hard work, dedication and years that he has put into his craft have paid off.ldquoI was gutted not to fly over, there have been other times when he has gone away and we havenrsquot been able to be there but with the magnitude of this fight, everyone wanted to be there to support him, but we were all cheering him on and screaming for him at the television.Danielle said the Taylor family are excited to celebrate when the world champion touches down in Scotland today , but Covid- restrictions are making it dficult.She said: ldquoWe are having to play it by ear because it is hard to book anything."Normally we would go into a hall or celebrate in a pub but there are only so many people you can have in aand there is no way you could only pick  people to celebrate, so we arenrsquot doing that.ldquoWe are hoping to be able to get an open-top bus for him, but we need to seethe council will allow that.Danielle was disappointed by the lack of national televised coverage of the fight.She said: ldquoIt is absolutely shocking that the fight wasnrsquot broadcast on a bigger  for others to be able to watch.ldquoThe older generation do not have smartphones, so they were struggling to watch it when it was on because it was streamed through an app."Danielle said Josh was flying home on Tuesday for some well-deserved time off.The couple got engaged in Dubai last December.Danielle said: "Hopefully he can take some time off so we can get our wedding planned and chill for a while."

title: picture-gallery-duke-duchess-cambridge-visit-heavy-sound-cockenzie
story: William and Catherine, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, were in Cockenzie yesterday as part of their ongoing tour of Scotland.The couple were visiting Heavy Sound, which works with the Scottish Violence Reduction Unit , a joint project backed by the police and the Scottish Government which tries to tackle the root causes of violence.During the visit, the Duke and Duchess saw young people doing martial arts, music production and bicycle maintenance, organised by community organisation Heavy Sound, which is based at the Cockenzie Hub on Edinburgh Road.Manager Thilo Pfander persuaded Kate to try her hand at making some EDMand at first the Duchess received some encouragement from her husband, who said: "Yeah, drop a beat in the background."Kate did produce a bass-heavy track but added a piercing synth sound over the top.William laughed and said: "Whats that "It sounded like a cat... It might catch on ndash in about a hundred years time!"After a few moments, William pleaded for it to stop,saying: "Its hurting my ears."He then added: "Im not sure its number one material yet."

title: spectators-welcomed-musselburgh-racecourse-afternoon
story: The East Lothian track will admit  pre-booked race spectators at noon todayin the first step towards resuming normal racing.The racecourse worked carefully with East Lothian Councils Safety Advisory Group to establish a raceday protocol ahead of the event.Alcohol and food can only be ordered but must be consumed at tables in a designated picnic area, while a two-metre distancing rule will be enforced throughout the course.Musselburgh Racecourse said in a post on Facebook today: ldquoThe track is in great condition today. Were thrilled to welcome back spectators for the first time since February !The sold-out event will host eight races, with the first beginning at .pm.The next spectator event at the Musselburgh track is The Edinburgh Cup Raceday on Saturday, June .Musselburghs popular Stobo Castle Ladies Day has been moved from August  to August  to give spectators the best chance of relaxed Covid- rules.For a full fixture list and to book tickets, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: national-lottery-scrapped-newsagents-new-licence
story: Newsagents are worried a new operator would want to accelerate online and app sales which could prove disastrous for local convenience stores.The Gambling Commission is set to announce whether Camelot will keep hold of the licence for a fourth term in the next six months.And according to The Grocer, nearly half of convenience retailerssay the National Lottery is more important to their business than ever.Sisal, Allwyn, Sugal  Damani and Camelot are currently in contention for the new licence, with Richard Bransonrsquos Virgin Group and Northern  Shell other companies rumoured to be applying., retailers across the UK currently work with Camelot, earning around % commission on each draw-based game.Jason Birks, deputy VP at the National Federation of Retail Newsagents , said: ldquoCurrently, the National Lottery does have an online presence but Irsquove heard that some of the bidders want to do a lot more online and from a high street point of view, and from the point of view of community-based retailing, we need to protect bricks and mortar.ldquoThose in government need to not only view online as the lsquotrendyrsquo thing to do but bear in mind that people still like to visit bricks and mortar retailing.One independent retailer told The Grocer: ldquoI donrsquot think Camelot deserve another licence as for the last few years they have been very average with limited innovation, mediocre support for retailers with too much red tape.ldquoA new licensee should create a fresh approach and more energy.A Camelot spokesperson said National Lottery retailers earned around pound, in commission on average in  .A statement read: "We fundamentally believe that The National Lotterys success ndash which culminated in record sales last year ndash is reliant on building and maintaining a healthy retail channel."Thats why weve invested heavily in retail at the same time as growing the largest digital lottery channel in the world by revenuehellip"While were unable to share specic details of our bid, we can say that Camelots philosophy remains the same ndash with retail being a cornerstone of our strategy. National Lottery retailers have been fantastic partners to us over the past  years and, as theyve always been there for us, they can expect our continued support."

title: heros-welcome-josh-taylor-boxer-arrives-home-prestonpans
story: Proud residents gathered outside the Prestoungrange Gothenburg to welcome home their own Tartan Tornado after he beat his American rival Jose Ramirez in Las Vegas this weekend.Josh was crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the world on Saturday after a stunning unanimous points victory.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the worldDedicated fans braved the cold and rain to catch a glimpse of the world champion as he arrived home.Josh, accompanied by his fianceacutee Danielle Murphy, slowed his car to soak in the adulation of the crowd that had gathered outside his local pub.One of the first to greet the heroic boxer was his dad, James .Diane Taylor, Joshs mum, said she was overwhelmed seeing her son again as he ed home from his history-making win.She added: "I feel absolutely amazing."The energy of him driving through was amazing because I was panicking there wasnt going to be anybody here because of a mix-up with the flights and everything, but when I saw everybody I was so pleased, it is brilliant."The crowd erupted into cheers and chants as the champion drove down High Street at pm.Lara Connerton and Kenny Ainslie came out to celebrate Joshs arrivalOne resident, Lara Connerton, said: "I am super proud, it is absolutely amazing."He stopped and spoke to everyone and he took photos with the children in the streets."He is absolutely lovely, a top guy.""We are going to go and have a pint to celebrate."Another, Kenny Ainslie, said: "Its lovely seeing him, we are so proud."The Courier was live from Prestonpans when Josh arrived ndash watch a short video of his arrival here.

title: heading
story: Carrie Williamson was with her son and daughter, Finlay and Bonnie Loftus, aged seven and five, and their bulldog Mable, when they saw the stone propped up against a fence by Prestoungrange Mining Museum, Prestonpans.Read More: Heros welcome for Josh Taylor as he arrives home in PrestonpansJosh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival Jose Ramirez with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion in Las Vegas on Saturday."The children were super excited to find it especially when they realised it was specially made for a world champion," said Carrie.The family, who live at Pinkie Braes, took a quick photo of the stone and put it back in its place for others to find and enjoy.Read More: Josh Taylors fiancee excited to plan wedding to the heroJosh, who ed to Scotland yesterday, was greeted with a herorsquos welcome as he passed through Prestonpans at pm.Supporters gathered outside the Prestongrange Gothenburg to cheer for the titleholder as he slowed his car to soak in the elated crowds.Read More: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed champion of the worldFans waved Scottish flags and signs on the High Street as Josh headed home to Haddington for some well-deserved rest.One sign read: lsquoHaud yir wheest Ramiz, your belts are coming tae the Pans.rsquoResidents from Northbank Road, Prestonpans, huddled together amid the cold on Saturday night to watch Joshrsquos fight on a projector.A banner on the street said: ldquoThis is my hometown, the place I was born in, no matter where I go itrsquos in my soul.ldquoMy feet may wander a thousand places, but my heart will lead me back home to Prestonpans.

title: lone-swan-finds-new-love-river-esk-musselburgh
story: Bonnie was taken to a new home on the River Esk when she abandoned her nest at Figgate Park, Portobello, after losing her partner Clyde.It appeared he had been in a fight with another male swanand had to be put to sleep.Sarah Auldsmith, Scottish SPCA senior animal rescue officer, said: ldquoWe were contacted back in April about an injured swan at Figgate Park.ldquoIt appeared a resident male swan, Clyde, had been in a fight with another male, resulting in a leg injury that made him unable to walk.ldquoClyde had also had bad arthritis for a number of years, which had been slowly getting worse.ldquoThis, coupled with him now being completely unable to stand, meant that he would not recover and the dficult decision was made to put him to sleep to end his suffering.She explained that Bonnie abandoned her nest about a month after losing Clyde.ldquoShe had been doing her best to incubate them but without her partner, and with her constantly being attacked by the new male, the eggs were unfortunately not viable, said Sarah.ldquoBonnie was moved to Musselburgh a couple of weeks ago and seems to be getting on well in her new environment.ldquoWe havenrsquot heardshersquos found a new mate yet but this is certainly a possibility as swans will often take up with another partner after their previous one has passed away.ldquoWhen she moved, Bonnie left her eggs in the nest and they have most likely been predated on since then.Photographer Angus Bathgate, from Wallyford, captured Bonnie on camera enjoying her new le on the Esk and it is thought she may have even have found love again, after being snapped with a new admirer.Mr Bathgate said that during a visit to the Esk, he was told by someone who was involved with the welfare of the swans that Bonnie could be singled out by the identication number on her tag.He added: ldquoIt made my day when Bonnie and her new mate chose to show their bonding together, which I captured on camera.Sarah appealed to the public: ldquoIf you discover any injured wildle, please contact our helpline on   .

title: newhailes-house-musselburgh-reopens-brand-new-visitor-attractions
story: The Palladian Villa, which boasts original furnishings and possessions from more than  years of inhabitants, has reopened with brand new visitor attractions.The National Trust for Scotland property has undergone restoration work to welcome visitors again after a sprinkler system mal and a moth infestation saw it close in February .The conservation charity has introduced a brand new visitor experience inside the house, with catering facilities available on the estate.Visitors can enjoy Weehailes Playpark and a new takeaway ice cream parlour and coffee shop, The Dairy.The dairy premises once provided milk, cream and butter for all those who lived and worked on the estate.The team at Newhailes has developed three new visitor tours, one of which can now be pre-booked at www.nts.org.ukThe first tour explores the last  years of le at Newhailes and the trustrsquos role in saving the house and estate.The second tour sheds further light on the property, telling the tales behind the art collections and objects in the house.The final tour is targeted at families and explores the home through storytelling it is suitable for those with young children.Claire Grant, operations manager for Edinburgh, said: ldquoWersquove been taking steps to revitalise Newhailes since before  and plans were further delayed when the pandemic hit.ldquoWe wanted to create a new experience that the local community could enjoy, in addition to offering a good-quality food and drinks experience.ldquoWersquore really excited to be welcoming visitors back to Newhailes House after what has been a very long period of closure and we hope they enjoy some of our new additions, like our Dairy and Stables Cafe.ldquoSo many people love this place, and we are really pleased to be able to welcome visitors from near and far back once again.ldquoAll of our properties across Edinburgh and the Lothians have been making visits as safe as possible."Pre-booking is in place at a few sites and there are smaller groups for house tours."She said that visitors should book their slot at Newhailes in advance to avoid any disappointment.Newhailes House is open to the public for tours from title: recipe-philips-famous-fonteluna-sugo---familys-favourite-sunday-lunch
story: It celebrates our iconic Fonteluna spicy sausage as one of our key products. Its secret recipe is held only by four family members. The sausage is made with % coarse-cut pure pork meat and fat, seasoned andair-dried for  days. The recipe has been handed down over five generations.Here is Philiprsquos Famous Fonteluna Sugo ndash our familyrsquos favourite for Sunday lunch.Ingredients x g Rega San Marzano tomatoes  fresh bay leaves teaspoons sea salt- tablespoons Fior Fiore extra virgin olive oil medium onion, finely chopped cloves garlic, finely choppedHalf Fonteluna sausage MethodPrepare the tomatoes. Use a sharp kne to remove the stalk root at the top of each of the tomatoes and hand crush the pulp into a bowl.Fill the empty tin a quarter full of warm water and rinse the tin of any extra juices. Add this liquid to the bowl.Tear the bay leaves in half and add them and the salt to the tomatoes.Set aside to infuse the flavours.Use a wide, heavy bottomed saucepan with lid.Add enough Fior Fiore extra virgin olive oil to cover the bottom of the saucepan and begin to warm through. Add the onion, turn in the oil. Allow to soften gently for two minutes.Add the chopped garlic, turn this in the oil and with the lid on the pot, very gently steam the onion and garlic for about - minutes until the onion is softened and translucent.Do not burn the garlic.Meanwhile, rinse the Fonteluna sausage in warm water so that the outer casing can be easily removed.Slice finely and add to the onions and garlic, continue sauteacuteing gently until the spices turn the oil a deep orange colour.At this stage turn up the heat and immediately add the tomatoes, stirring to ensure tomatoes and oil are completely blended.Cook on a very high heat for  minutes to amalgamate all the flavours and then turn the heat to a simmer and cook very gently with the lid balanced on a wooden spoon for - minutes until the sugo has reduced by a third. Check seasoning.Use a g pkt of De Cecco Rigatoni and serve with a mountain of freshly grated Parmigiano Reggiano.All ingredients are available from Valvona  Crolla.

title: andrew-dunlop-stop-squabbling---strengthen-links-uk-scottish-governments
story: If polls could express emotions then I like to imagine this is the kind of exasperation to which a poll published after the recent elections was giving voice. Commissioned by Our Scottish Future, the pro-Union think tank, it had two headlines. Less than a quarter of Scots think that the Scottish and UK Governments cooperate well today.Nearly three-quarters want better cooperation. Not earth-shattering you might say. Human beings working together ndash itrsquos what we do, right  Amazingly, the poll found  per cent who disagreed. I had no idea the professional political class was so large.Okay, so that last bit is a bit unfair. However, politics is a brutal and competitive business. Greasy poles are not climbed by being nice to your opponents. Point scoring is second nature. Little wonder the population watches on wearily, itching to knock heads together.Nowhere is an inability to rub along more clear than in the fractious relationship between the Scottish and UK Governments. Lack of trust and confidence is re on both sides. UK ministers question whether Scottish counterparts, whose mission is to break up the country, are acting in good faith. Scottish ministers complain the UK Government disrespects their constitutional position.:Coronavirus: Pandemic: Take responsibility  Notyoure a Tory ministerAs in any troubled relationship both sides have a point. I recall extolling to a senior SNP leader the virtues of improving how the UK works. His reply was short and commendably frank: ldquoIrsquove no interest in strengthening the Union. And last year a senior UK Government lsquoinsiderrsquo vouchsafed to this newspaperrsquos UK Political Editor the thought that Boris Johnson ldquooutranks Nicola Sturgeon and ldquohas the pips on the collar.These remarks betray attitudes, which to outsiders appear petty and tiresome. The UK Government springs on devolved administrations a nasty surprise in the form of the UK Internal Market Bill. The Scottish Government refuses to collaborate on improving Scotlandrsquos connections with the rest of the UK. And wonrsquot play ball on developing Freeports, preferring exceptionalist Scottish Greenports ndash asports canrsquot be both free and green.For both, this is short-sighted. Separating Scotland from the rest of the UK is a very bad idea. However,thatrsquos your poison, is it really smart to demonstrate yoursquore incapable of working constructively with your nearest neighbour One whose currency you intend to use on departure, whilst leaving monetary policy in its central bankrsquos hands. And one on whose goodwill yoursquore relying to negotiate favourable lsquoScexitrsquo terms. Thatrsquos why Alex Salmond used to warble on about Scotlandrsquos place in six Unions ndash including a UK social union ndash and turning Scotland from surly lodger to good neighbour.If you think wersquore better together, then the job is surely to show Scots the value of having two governments batting for them that within the UK, Scotland doesnrsquot have to rely on a neighbourrsquos goodwill. Because when the UK Government negotiates with the Scottish Government a new post-Brexit subsidy regime, governance of the UK Shared Prosperity Fund, internal market exemptions or Scotlands fiscal framework, itrsquos not promoting Englandrsquos interests, but those of the whole country including Scotland.Fostering greater trust and confidence isnrsquot impossible. Building better relationships, however, requires investment of time and effort.Sadly, itrsquos not de rigueur these days to speak warmly of David Cameron. Yet in  Nicola Sturgeon said this about him: ldquoDavid Cameron, whose politics and mine are very far apart, always managed to have a personal rapport. You could sit with David and have a fairly frank discussion, agree on the things you could agree and accept you disagree on everything , and have a bit of banter as well. The fruits of that relationship were a fiscal framework agreed, City and Growth Deals for every part of Scotland struck and much more besides.:Andy Maciver: How Ruth Davidson could have become First Minister ndash an alternative historyWith the elections behind us, is it too much to hope for a move from Cold War to a new spirit of detente  More in tune with the national mood and an overwhelming desire to pick ourselves up after Covid.Early signs encourage. The PM is right to reach out to devolved leaders, inviting them to an early summit. And just before the recent election campaign, the UK Government published proposals, developed jointly with devolved governments, to strengthen how they work together. They reveal an impressive package of necessary reforms, most of which is already agreed. Remaining gaps seem easily bridgeable.Are they really going to fall out over what to call the new devolution council  Word of advice ndash the more clunkily contrived the name, the more likely the media will apply a colloquial, short-hand, alternative.And some UK ministers are apparently reluctant for the Foreign Office to establish an inter-ministerial forum for dialogue with devolved administrations because foreign policy is reserved. This is the tin-hatted defensiveness too often bedevilling inter-governmental relations. Is this really the ditch in which some ministers are prepared to die rather than have a package agreed  Unless Scottish ministersrsquo passports are to be revoked, wouldnrsquot it be better to take opportunities to explain to them why trashing abroad the UKrsquos brand isnrsquot the best way of promoting Scotlandrsquos So get that package of reform agreed as soon as possible, Prime Minister. Wouldnrsquot that be the best shot in the arm for a country in need of a booster at this watershed moment Andrew Dunlop was an adviser to former Conservative prime minister David Cameron during the  independence referendumOur columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: agenda-must-adopt-feeley-report-recommendations
story: AS the CEO of a Scottish charity, I can truthfully say that the past  months have been the most dficult and challenging I have faced in my career.I have been in post at the Eric Liddell Centre in Edinburgh for several years now and I am proud to head up a dedicated team of staff and to work with a very supportive board of trustees.While our centre is usually a busy and vibrant community hub, our speciality is dementia day care and support for carers.Our core group of service users are vulnerable and often isolated. When we had to close down our Centre once Covid hit, we knew we had to somehow keep our services going.With lack of income from the groups who use the centre, we have suffered a financial haemorrhage, resulting in a shortfall of pound, and I recognise there is a long road to recovery.Finances notwithstanding, I can only pay tribute to our board of trustees who continued to support and enable us to keep operational and my amazing team which turned our operations into a online continuation of service within  hours.The team worked within the Covid restrictions but also managed to get a range of services up and running, covering everything from delivery of homemade lunches to prescriptions pickup and delivery.Since the May  Holyrood elections and the Scottish Government announcement of new ministerial posts, I welcome Humza Yousaf as Scotlandrsquos new Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care. I wish him success and look forward to working with him.I urge our Scottish Parliament MSPs to implement the recommendations contained in the Independent Review of Adult Social Carethat was published in Scotland in February .People have said for years that it makes absolute sense to combine our health and social care systems, followed by the inevitable caveat that it would be too expensive to achieve this.However, in the last  months, faced with a massive health crisis, bureaucracy and its rule books were thrown out the window and we discovered just how quickly and efficiently major things could be achieved.I ask our new Scottish Parliament to learn from Covid- and recognise this is a unique opportunity to restructure, rebuild and refinance a workable new health and social care model, where funding is adequate to provide for the needs of all the people in Scotland.This includes funding for local health and social care partnerships. The Feeley Report asks for a clear distinction between the range of services provided for older people who have a neurological condition such as dementia and others with complex health needs, as the needs of each group are signicantly dferent.Looking to the future, the question is not whether Scotland can afford to implement the Feeley recommendations but put much more simply, we cannot afford not to do so.John MacMillan is CEO of the Eric Liddell Centre

title: agenda-not-late-build-world-class-stem-education-system
story: A REVIEW of Scotlandrsquos Curriculum for Excellencendash the cornerstone of Scottish education ndashwill be published in June, and should be regarded as a matter of great signicance to the teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics ndash Stem for short.Calls for an independent evaluation of CfE have been years in the making, and the recommendations from the review being carried out by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development , will undoubtedly be pored over by policymakers.The Learned Societiesrsquo Group on Scottish Stem Educationsubmitted oral evidence to the OECDrsquos review, drawing together key issues in need of further national action. As we await OECDrsquos final word on the curriculum, we take this opportunity to highlight some of our concerns.CfE began as a promising development, and it is still laudable for its forward-thinking and holistic aims. Itrsquos not too late for these ambitions to be realised and used to build a world-class Stem education system, however we must first recognise the wider context that has hindered its delivery. Even the best-designed Stem curriculum will falter in the face of pervasive and persistent structural challenges.Reforming the senior phase led to a narrowing of subject choice, sowing the initial seeds for a review of CfE and contributing to declines in enrolment in Stem subjects at SCQF levels  and  since .Secondly, Scotland faces shortages of subject-specialist teachers, and secondary school laboratory technicians, both of which are critical to delivering the kind of engrossing Stem experiences which inspire lelong interest in these subjects.More widely, classrooms are having to resort to multi-course teaching ndash the dficult practice of teaching more than one course in the same timeslot ndash to combat the effects of limited staff capacity and timetabling pressures.Finally, primary teachers can lack confidence in teaching Stem an increased focus on Stem subjects in primary teacher education, both initial and career-long, is required to build teachersrsquo knowledge and understanding in these subjects.Among its widespread havoc, Covid- upended many of our traditional approaches to education, from empty classrooms to exam cancellations. Many of these adjustments were profoundly stressful and often had the greatest impact on the most disadvantaged learners. However, they also prompted important questions and challenged longstanding assumptions of what it means to assess learning.As the pandemic and its aftershocks subside, some of these changes may persist and gain further traction. There could be an opportunity to reconfigure assessments to improve their effectiveness and reduce teacher workloads. However, rather than rushing into any large-scale educational upheavals on the back of post-Covid recovery, any lessons learned will need to be sensitively applied, ensuring they bring genuine benefit for teachers, parents, and pupils alike.Stem education in Scotland faces several obstacles. While valuable in its own right, its role in building the next generation of problem-solvers and keeping Scotlandrsquos economy and research sectors internationally competitive cannot be denied. With the right systemic changes, Curriculum for Excellence can live up to its name ndash and support an exceptional Stem education system in the process.Professor David Cole-Hamilton FRSE is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and interim chair of the LSG.

title: coronavirus-scotland-restrictions-eased-take-flights-holiday
story: Damn you, every one, on yesterday mornings am flight from Edinburgh to Faro. I have a very finely curated list of must-visit places and Ive always been careful to choose my flights wisely, not wanting to waste carbon footprint or annual leave or money on a holiday for holidays sake.Fly me anywhere now, though. Im desperate to see family in Australia and New Zealand. Zanzibar and the Galapagos and New Orleans still call to me but at this rate Ill happily jet to Edinburgh just for the experience.Though... just because we can now fly overseas again, should we John Swinney said yesterday that travel is still only permitted for essential reasons. When the BBC spoke to passengers preparing to depart for Portugal they listed their reasons as a reward after a year of studying that its "always nice" to get a bit of sunshine and after a year of restrictions, travel is "well deserved".Fair enough. "Essential" is a term open to interpretation. For some, a wedding is essential. For others, more pragmatic others, a wedding is possibly the least essential event you could dream up.A last visit to someone ill a meeting with a new infant - these are unarguably essential.A holiday for holidays sake takes a bit of rhetoric round about to justy it, but you can justy a holiday after  months of pandemic restrictions without too much heavy lting.Looking at the green light travel options Im pleased to Australia and New Zealand on the green list, for personal reasons, but they wont let us in. Good luck finding a straightforward route to the South Georgia and Sandwich Islands - I suspect many would have to Google them first.St Helena, Tristan de Cunha and Ascension Island are fairly outre choices as well. My friend Janet went to St Helena a few years ago. She had a lovely time but the trip involved an RAF troop carrier and a voyage on the last remaining Royal Mail Ship.So options are limited for green lights. Last week a flight left England for Spain and, on arrival, those who were there for a holiday were put on another flight and sent home again. Amber gambling might not be wise.How to decide whether to fly. The Scottish Government advice, as described, is to avoid overseas travel. Yesterday, Dr Jillian Evans, head of health intelligence at NHS Grampian, told BBC Radios Good Morning Scotland programme that case numbers are rising again and a third wave is not ruled out."It would be far better," she said, "And far safer to do the cautious thing now and plan your summer holiday for next year."It seems like a lot of buck passing. If people are chided for choosing to go on holiday then they can point to the fact the airlines are selling tickets abroad.If the airlines are pulled up for the fact they are selling tickets abroad they can point to the government, which has given the green light for them to go ahead.If theres condemnation on the government for encouraging overseas travel then - get out of jail free - they can point right back to the people making the choice to go and say its all about personal responsibility.It feels like a blame game in the style of pass the parcel.Its hard to blame airlines for laying on flights to holiday destinations. The industry has been devastated by coronavirus - along with airports - and is looking at years of recovery ahead. Of course the travel industry is going to restart as soon as it can.This disconnect between the Scottish and UK governments is jarring also - caution here and encouragement there.Is leaving people to exercise common sense on this issue the best way forward in lockdown easing, particularly when those in charge cant decide Doors are already cross checked and to manual so we can but hope for a safe landing on the other side.

title: issue-day-les-dennis-now-opera-star
story: Did I read that right  Les Dennis Yes, the comedian-turned-actor will make his operatic debut at the age of  in the Gilbert and Sullivan opera, playing Sir Joseph Porter. The ENOrsquos artistic director Annilese Miskimmon said that Dennis ldquocompletely blew us away in the audition process. He was given the job the same day.This isnrsquot for Comic Relief, is it No. You are such a cynic.Are we talking about the same Les Dennis  The guy from The Russ Abbot Show  The presenter of Family Fortunes One and the same. But yoursquove clearly not been paying attention. Dennis has long shown an ability for reinvention that extends far beyond sending himself up in Ricky Gervaisrsquos sitcom Extras. Hersquos tuned up in soaps , performed at the Edinburgh Fringe, appeared in musicals in Londonrsquos West End and been part of such touring shows as Hairspray, Yasmina Rezarsquos play Art and The Addams Family, in which he played Uncle Fester.In  he even performed with the Royal Shakespeare Comedy in Restoration plays The Provoked We and Venice Preserved, winning rave reviews in the process.OK, I clearly havenrsquot been paying attention. What has the man himself got to say about all this ldquoItrsquos good to take people by surprise and take myself equally by surprise, Dennis has told the .ldquoIf Irsquod been doing the cabaret circuit or the club circuit or the Saturday night telly that was around in the eighties, I wouldnrsquot be around anymore, because those shows have fallen by the wayside. So, I have had to keep changing.He is not the first comedian to have altered course over the years, though.Of course not. Max Wall, the famous music hall clown ended up performing plays by Samuel Beckett. Les Dawson wrote novels and Rikki Fulton turned up in the  film version of the thriller Gorky Park playing a KGB officer. Fulton, along with Denise Coffey, also co-wrote A Wee Touch Orsquo Class, a Scottish adaptation of Molierersquos Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme for the Fringe. He even performed the lead role.Whoopi Goldberg was nominated for an Oscar for her role in Steven Spielbergrsquos film version of Alice Walkerrsquos novel The Colour Purple back in . ldquoWe lost a serious actress when Goldberg started playing nuns and "Star Trek" characters, the late film critic Roger Ebert once said.Does Bill Bailey winning Strictly count Possibly not. But, then again, Bailey is a classically-trained musician with an Associate Diploma from London College of Music.

title: ferries-faroes-model-offers-islands-rule-edinburgh-gourock
story: Accordingly, it is a little puzzling to find that the two Ministers in the Scottish Government appointed to these remits would be more at home in Brechin than Barra, more naturally in tune with the road to Dundee than making their way to Stornoway.Given the ferry crisis afflicting the west coast, every element of which ends up at the Scottish Governmentrsquos door, there is an overwhelming case for the issue to have some priority perhaps even the attention of Cabinet Secretary Michael Matheson.However, Mr Matheson ndash whose exciting new title is Cabinet Secretary for Net Zero, Energy and Transport ndash has been the invisible man when it comes to ferries, several barge poles separating him from the sources of maritime disarray.I doubtwe will see Mr Matheson hurrying into the Ferguson Marine yard to take responsibility, any time soon.That privilege may belong to Graeme Dey, MSP for Angus South and now Transport Minister whose  listed responsibilities include ldquoferries inc. CMAL. Well, good luck with that. Without any background in the subject, he will probably follow advice from those whose long-range genius created the problems in the first place.:Brian Wilson: SNP hammered hospitality but guaranteed George Square chaosThen we have the Cabinet Secretary for Rural Affairs and ndash very much a late tag-on ndash Islands, Mairi Gougeon, MSP for Angus South. The previous ldquoand Islands Minister was Paul Wheelhouse, from the Borders, who for some reason became Minister for Fergusonrsquos although, unlike Mr Dey, he was not a Transport Minister. So many Ministers, so little continuity, so much title-shuffling.The common characteristic is that none of them has constituency interests in either ferries or islands. The SNP have six MSPs in the Highlands and Islandsand none has ever been allowed near either role. This is consistent with nobody from the communities served by CMAL and CalMac being on the boards of either.I doubtthere is a coastal country in Europe, perhaps the world, where the same prohibition would be tolerated. Certainly not in the Scandinavian lands which are so often held up as role models ndash which set me thinking about the Faroes and why the idea of autonomy for the Scottish islands should be taken seriously.Ferries are only the current example. It is inconceivable that an islands-based ferry company could do a worse job. Indeed, the Western Isles Council has just put forward a very coherent plan, both short-term and medium-term, for escaping from the current mess. It should, I suggest, be Mr Deyrsquos preferred reading before he gets to the civil service brief.It would also create enough jobs to be transformational in island communities. For decades in the islands, ldquoGourock has been shorthand for mismanagement, nepotism and worse. It is an anachronism dating back to the  merger of MacBrayne with the Caledonian Steam Packet Companythat the whole show is run from there rather than some of the places it is supposed serve.The same reasoning can be applied to every distinctively island public service, run from afar. Crofting regulation is another easy example. The whole thing is a shambles regulated from a centralised bureaucracy in Inverness. It is impossible to believe it would not be more pro-active and alert to depressing realities on the groundit operated at localised levels.:Brian Wilson: Theres nothing green about iding Britain or closing down the North SeaNeither is the argument confined to the public sector. The first person I heard espouse the Faroes as a role model was the late Ian Noble who had gone there in the s and learned how economic development and cultural renaissance went hand in hand. He applied that principle in Skye, particularly as founder of Sabhal Mor Ostaig, Scotlandrsquos Gaelic college.The lesson has never been built on. Greater political and administrative autonomy would keep people in the islands ndash just as in Faroes where population has gone from , in  to almost , today. Natural entrepreneurism would flourish. How curious that one of the biggest fish farmers in our own islands was recently bought by a Faroese company. Could it ever happen the other way round The neo-colonialism exercised by Edinburgh should be replaced by serious decentralisation. No ldquosubsidy is required. The pretence Scotlandrsquos islands donrsquot pay their way is ridiculous. From Shetlandrsquos oil to Islayrsquos whisky, not to mention a disproportionate contribution to Scotlandrsquos global images and a host of world class products, the islands pay their dues many times over to UK and Scottish coffers.Anyone who actually believes in devolution would see the case for islandsrsquo autonomy ndash not as a threat or challenge but merely as a means to better, fairer, more creative governance.The same can and should be argued in urban settings. Look at the great success of the metro Mayors in England and Wales, delivering for their cities and regions because they can stand up to central government. In contrast, Scotland has a higher degree of centralisation than ever before. The challenge to that mindset could start in the islands and work its way in.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.
